sect1.title: CASE 43
sect1.para: A 32-year-old woman with a 6-week history of diarrhea secondary to ulcerative colitis on infliximab presented to the emergency department (ED). She had returned from a trip to Provence in France 4 days previously, and over the 3 days following her return her diarrhea had worsened. She presented to the ED with a temperature of 38.5°C, blood pressure of 90/60 mm Hg, and white blood cell count of 14,500/μl with 90% neutrophils. Two sets of blood cultures were obtained. She was admitted to the infectious disease service, where she was begun on 2 g of ceftriaxone intravenously every 12 hours.

listitem.para: 1. Explain why you think this person had a history of 6 weeks of diarrhea.
2. What is infliximab? Why was this patient being treated with infliximab?

sect1.para: Both blood cultures became positive after 16 to 20 hours of incubation. The Gram stain in Fig. 43.1 is from one of the blood cultures; the Gram stain from the second blood culture was the same.

listitem.para: 3. How do you interpret this Gram stain?

sect1.para: After the microbiologist reviewed the Gram stain from the patient’s positive blood culture, he asked the infectious disease team to obtain a more detailed travel history, especially what foods the woman had eaten in Provence. Of note, she said she ate soft cheeses, steak tartare, rare leg of lamb, and many fresh fruits and vegetables.

listitem.para: 4. What did the microbiologist learn from the Gram stain that raised concerns about her food history? What Gram-positive bacilli that can cause bacteremia are associated with food consumption, and what foods that she consumed are of particular concern?
5. What role did infliximab have in the development of the patient’s infection?
6. Was the initial antimicrobial choice appropriate for this patient? Explain.
7. Although it was not done in this case, would a pregnancy test have been prudent?

sect1.para: 1. Ulcerative colitis is a chronic inflammatory disease of the colon and rectum that is frequently associated with periods of chronic diarrhea followed by periods of remission. Diarrhea in individuals with ulcerative colitis will often be bloody (1).

2. Infliximab belongs to a class of therapeutic agents called immunomodulators (2, 3). Immunomodulators are used to treat a variety of chronic conditions associated with immune system disorders, including rheumatoid arthritis, inflammatory bowel disease (including ulcerative colitis), psoriasis, ankylosing spondylitis, lymphoma, chronic lymphocytic leukemia, and systemic lupus erythematosus. Immunomodulators fit into two broad categories: biologics, which are primarily monoclonal antibodies, which act against specific targets in the immune system, neutralizing their activity; or small molecules, which also inhibit the activity of specific immune system targets. Infliximab is a human-mouse chimeric monoclonal antibody that inhibits the activity of tumor necrosis factor α (TNF-α). TNF-α is a proinflammatory cytokine that impacts a variety of inflammatory pathways. Inhibition of TNF-α by infliximab was shown in two randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trials to produce a dose-dependent, statistically significant clinical response (2, 4). As a result, infliximab has become a standard therapy for treatment of moderate to severe ulcerative colitis (1). All immunomodulators carry a “box warning.” FDA mandates these warnings be present in a box in the drug package insert. They describe severe adverse events observed in individuals taking these agents. Television commercials for different drugs carry these warnings at the end, often in rushed language.

3. The organism is a Gram-positive bacillus. The morphology of the Gram-positive bacillus is important, as we will learn as we work through this case. Multiple morphotypes of Gram-positive bacilli are encountered in patients with bacteremia as well as other types of infections. Empiric therapy for the organisms discussed here may differ, so understanding the different Gram-positive bacilli morphotypes has clinical significance. The morphotype here is consistent with the organism causing this patient’s infection.

When seen in blood cultures, the genera with the Gram stain morphology shown in Fig. 43.1 are most likely Corynebacterium and Cutibacterium. Both have similar morphologies to the patient’s organism seen in Fig 43.1, but Corynebacterium spp. tend to be more club-shaped and clustered, while Cutibacterium spp. are more curved and often in a spider-like arrangement.

Figure 43.2 shows large Gram-variable (left panel) and -positive (right panel) bacilli. Gram-variable bacilli (left panel) are exactly that; some are Gram positive (purple) and some are Gram negative (pink). Three genera of bacteria with this Gram stain morphology encountered clinically are Lactobacillus spp., Bacillus spp., and Clostridium spp. The boxy, Gram-positive morphology in the right panel is more consistent with Bacillus spp. and Clostridium spp.; however, certain Lactobacillus species may share a similar morphology.

figure.title: Figure 43.2 Gram stain of large, Gram-variable (left panel) and boxy, Gram-positive (right panel) bacilli. Left panel courtesy of CDC-PHIL (#1058), right panel courtesy of Sixto Leal. (Magnification, ×1,000.)

textobject.para: A microscopic photograph displaying purple, rod-shaped bacterial cells scattered and aggregated on a light background.

sect1.para: Bacillus spp. can cause serious infections such as anthrax (Bacillus anthracis) and Clostridium spp. cause gas gangrene (Clostridium septicum and Clostridium perfringens). They can also be contaminants in blood cultures. On the other hand, Lactobacillus spp. are almost always a contaminant in blood cultures. If found in multiple blood culture sets (an exceedingly rare occurrence), it may indicate that the patient has endocarditis.

Another distinctive positive Gram stain is seen in Fig. 43.3. The organism is thin, pleiotropic (many forms), and may have pseudo-branching. This organism belongs to the genus Actinomyces, and this particular Gram stain is from an aspirate of a brain abscess. Actinomyces species are anaerobic bacteria associated with brain, lung, and jaw abscesses.

The final Gram stain (Fig. 43.4) shows a “beaded” Gram-positive organism due to the irregular, bead-like staining pattern. This staining appearance is found in what are called “higher-order” bacteria. The two most common genera with this appearance on Gram stain are Mycobacterium and Nocardia. This particular organism is Mycobacterium abscessus complex recovered from a blood culture.

sect1.para: 4. The Gram stain of the organism detected from blood culture shows relatively small, Gram-positive bacilli with straight, parallel walls characteristic of Listeria monocytogenes.

It is almost always obtained by the consumption of contaminated food. Foods most frequently contaminated by Listeria include soft cheeses, which may not be made with pasteurized milk; processed meats (cold cuts); and fresh fruits and vegetables that are contaminated with either animal or human feces (5).

5. Listeria is a facultative intracellular pathogen. TNFα is a proinflammatory cytokine that recruits and activates neutrophils and macrophages, enhancing their ability to kill bacteria. Monoclonal antibodies that inhibit TNF-α activity place individuals at risk for infection with a wide variety of intracellular pathogens, including Listeria, Mycobacterium tuberculosis, and the dimorphic fungus Histoplasma capsulatum (see the infliximab box warning for other organisms for which she is at risk) (6).

6. There is very limited information in the literature about bacteremia in individuals with ulcerative colitis. Ceftriaxone was likely chosen because of its ease of administration (once or twice daily) and broad spectrum of activity. Listeria is clinically resistant to ceftriaxone and as such is not a good choice for treating this patient (7). By knowing the patient’s history, especially her dietary one, coupled with the blood culture Gram stain result, the patient’s clinicians could switch her to an appropriate antimicrobial at least 18 to 24 hours earlier than if they had to wait for a subculture of the organism to grow so it could be identified. The patient was switched to ampicillin and made an uneventful recovery.

7. Vertical transmission of Listeria carries a significant risk of fetal or neonatal mortality. In the largest outbreak of food-borne Listeria on record, 50% of the >900 cases occurred during pregnancy, with close to 43% occurring in neonates, with a 28% mortality (8). Early-onset disease occurred in 95% of neonates. Fetal loss occurred in 27 of 59 infected pregnant woman (46%). These data support vertical transmission as the major mode of transmission. Letting the individual, if pregnant, know of the potential risks of eating soft cheeses, cold cuts, and undercooked meat to the fetus would seem prudent. In addition, clinicians should be aware that outbreaks may occur with other types of foods. Examples of Listeria outbreaks with other foods include stone fruits (peaches, plums, nectarines), ice cream, and leafy greens (9, 10).

listitem.para: L. monocytogenes is a Gram-positive bacillus that can cause sepsis and meningitis, primarily but not exclusively in immunocompromised hosts, including the elderly, neonates, and individuals receiving immunosuppressive agents.
It can contaminate a variety of foods, including unpasteurized dairy products, processed meats, and fresh fruits and vegetables that come in contact with fecally contaminated water or soil.

Listeria is found in the box warnings of several immunosuppressive monoclonal antibodies, including infliximab, which inhibits the activity of TNF-α. Infliximab is a commonly used therapeutic for treating moderate to severe ulcerative colitis and other autoimmune diseases.
Listeria is clinically resistant to all cephalosporins, including ceftriaxone. Ampicillin is the drug of choice.
Vertical transmission of Listeria is associated with high rates of fetal demise and neonatal mortality.
